instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: What are transformers used for in the electric distribution system?
output: Transformers (object name: ElectricLoadCenter:Transformer) are an integral part of the electric distribution system. They have two broad applications closely related to building energy simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: What is the purpose of distribution transformers?
output: First transformers are used to lower the voltage of electricity from utility primary circuits to customer secondary circuits and in this case they are called distribution transformers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: What voltage do distribution transformers reduce utility distribution lines to?
output: Distribution transformers reduce the voltage on utility distribution lines (34.5 kV or less) to a lower secondary voltage (600 V or less) suitable for customer equipment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: How are distribution transformers categorized?
output: Distribution transformers are usually categorized according to the medium used for cooling and insulation (liquid or air) the voltage class that they serve (low or medium) and the number of phases (single phase or three phase).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: What do liquid-immersed transformers rely on for cooling?
output: Liquid-immersed transformers rely on oil or other fire resistant liquid around the coils for cooling.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: How do dry type transformers achieve insulation and cooling?
output: In contrast dry type transformers rely only on the natural convection of air for insulation and cooling.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: What is the secondary voltage from a medium-voltage transformer usually at?
output: The secondary voltage from a medium-voltage transformer is usually at 277 V for single phase and 480 V for three phase.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: What are common uses for 480 V three-phase and 277 V single-phase power?
output: This secondary voltage can be directly used as 480 V three-phase power for large motors or as 277 V single-phase power for some fluorescent lighting.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: Why are low-voltage transformers needed in most industrial and commercial facilities?
output: However for most industrial and commercial facilities low-voltage transformers are needed to reduce the above voltages further to 208/120 V.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: What are common 120 V loads?
output: Common 120 V loads are wall plugs and incandescent lighting.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: Who typically owns liquid-immersed transformers?
output: Most liquid-immersed transformers are owned by utilities and they are of the medium-voltage type.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: Who typically owns dry type transformers?
output: Virtually all dry type transformers are owned by commercial and industrial customers (Barnes et al. 1996).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: What is the difference between medium-voltage and low-voltage dry type transformers?
output: Of the dry type transformers those of the medium-voltage type are generally special-order items while those of the low-voltage type are commodity items.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: What standard covers the efficiency requirement of distribution transformers?
output: The efficiency requirement of distribution transformers is covered by the NEMA (National Electrical Manufactures Association) Standard TP 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Transformers -> text
input: Which standard will ASHRAE 90.1-2010 cite for the efficiency requirement of low-voltage dry type transformers?
output: ASHRAE 90.1-2010 will cite the NEMA Standard TP 1 to stipulate the efficiency requirement for the low-voltage dry type.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What are distribution transformers used for?
output: Distribution transformers are used to connect primary circuits to customer secondary circuits and to output surplus power from onsite generators to the electricity grid.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: How do distribution transformers reduce voltage?
output: Distribution transformers reduce the voltage on utility distribution lines (34.5 kV or less) to a lower secondary voltage (600 V or less) suitable for customer equipment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: How are distribution transformers categorized?
output: Distribution transformers are categorized according to the medium used for cooling and insulation (liquid or air) the voltage class that they serve (low or medium) and the number of phases (single phase or three phase).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What do liquid-immersed transformers rely on for cooling?
output: Liquid-immersed transformers rely on oil or other fire resistant liquid around the coils for cooling.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What do dry type transformers rely on for insulation and cooling?
output: Dry type transformers rely only on the natural convection of air for insulation and cooling.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What is the purpose of medium-voltage transformers?
output: Medium-voltage transformers step from utility line voltage down to a lower secondary voltage depending on the application.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What is the usual secondary voltage from a medium-voltage transformer for single and three phase?
output: The secondary voltage from a medium-voltage transformer is usually at 277 V for single phase and 480 V for three phase.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: How is the secondary voltage used in industrial and commercial facilities?
output: The secondary voltage can be directly used as 480 V three-phase power for large motors or as 277 V single-phase power for some fluorescent lighting. However for most industrial and commercial facilities low-voltage transformers are needed to reduce the above voltages further to 208/120 V.

input: What are common 120 V loads?
output: Common 120 V loads are wall plugs and incandescent lighting.

output: Most liquid-immersed transformers are owned by utilities and they are of the medium-voltage type.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What is the difference between medium-voltage and low-voltage dry type transformers?
output: Of the dry type transformers those of the medium-voltage type are generally special-order items while those of the low-voltage type are commodity items.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: Which standard covers the efficiency requirement of distribution transformers?
output: The efficiency requirement of distribution transformers is covered by the NEMA (National Electrical Manufacturers Association) Standard TP 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text

output: ASHRAE 90.1-2010 will cite the NEMA Standard TP 1 to stipulate the efficiency requirement for the low-voltage dry type distribution transformers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What are the two main types of energy losses in transformers?
output: There are two main types of energy losses in transformers: no load loss and load loss.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What is no load loss in transformers?
output: The no load loss comes primarily from the switching of the magnetic fields in the core material and is also called the core loss. It is roughly constant and exists continuously in the core material as long as the transformer is energized.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What is load loss in transformers?
output: The load loss comes from the electrical resistance in the windings when there is a load on the transformer and it is also called the winding loss. The load (winding) loss is proportional to the load squared with a small temperature correction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: How is the total energy loss in a transformer at time t calculated?
output: The total energy loss in a transformer at time t is calculated as: TL(t) = NL + LL(t) = NL + LL*P(t)^2*f_T(t)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does TL(t) represent in the equation for total energy loss?
output: TL(t) is the total energy loss at time t (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does LL(t) represent in the equation for total energy loss?
output: LL(t) is the load loss at time t (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does P(t) represent in the equation for total energy loss?
output: P(t) is the per unit load at time t.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does f_T(t) represent in the equation for total energy loss?
output: f_T(t) is the temperature correction factor for the load loss at time t.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: How is the per unit load at time t calculated?
output: The per unit load at time t is calculated as: P(t) = Load(t) / S_B

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does Load(t) represent in the equation for per unit load?
output: Load(t) is the transformer load at time t (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does S_B represent in the equation for per unit load?
output: S_B is the transformer nameplate rating (VA).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: How is the temperature correction factor at time t calculated?
output: The temperature correction factor at time t is calculated as: f_T(t) = L_dc * (R(t) / R_ref) + L_eddy * (R_ref / R(t))

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does L_dc represent in the equation for the temperature correction factor?
output: L_dc is the per unit load loss due to electrical resistance.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does L_eddy represent in the equation for the temperature correction factor?
output: L_eddy is the per unit load loss due to eddy currents.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does R(t) represent in the equation for the temperature correction factor?
output: R(t) is the winding electrical resistance at time t.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does R_ref represent in the equation for the temperature correction factor?
output: R_ref is the winding electrical resistance at the full load reference conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: How is the ratio of winding electrical resistance calculated?
output: The ratio of winding electrical resistance is calculated as: R(t) / R_ref = (F + T_winding(t) + T_amb(t)) / (F + T_windingref + T_ambref)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( TL(t) \) represent?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( LL(t) \) represent?
output: \( LL(t) \) is the load loss at time t (W)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( P(t) \) represent?
output: \( P(t) \) is the per unit load at time t

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( f_T(t) \) represent?
output: \( f_T(t) \) is the temperature correction factor for the load loss at time t.

input: How is the per unit load at time t calculated?

input: What does \( Load(t) \) represent?

output: The temperature correction factor at time t is calculated as: \( f_T(t) = L_dc*\\fracR(t)R_ref + L_eddy*\\fracR_refR(t) \)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( L_dc \) represent?
output: \( L_dc \) is the per unit load loss due to electrical resistance

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text

output: \( L_eddy \) is the per unit load loss due to eddy currents

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( R(t) \) represent?
output: \( R(t) \) is the winding electrical resistance at time t

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( R_ref \) represent?
output: \( R_ref \) is the winding electrical resistance at the full load reference conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: How is the ratio of winding electrical resistance calculated?
output: The ratio of winding electrical resistance is calculated as: \( \\fracR(t)R_ref = \\fracF + T_winding(t) + T_amb(t)F + T_windingref + T_ambref \)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( F \) represent?
output: \( F \) is the thermal coefficient of resistance for the winding material ( = 225 for aluminum and 234.5 for copper)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( T_windingref \) represent?
output: \( T_windingref \) is the winding temperature rise at the full load reference conditions (°C)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( T_winding(t) \) represent?
output: \( T_winding(t) \) is the winding temperature rise at time t (°C)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( T_ambref \) represent?
output: \( T_ambref \) is the ambient temperature at the reference condition ( = 20°C)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( T_amb(t) \) represent?
output: \( T_amb(t) \) is the ambient temperature at time t (°C)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What is the assumption for ambient temperature if a thermal zone is not specified?
output: The Ambient temperature \( T_amb(t) \) is equal to the zone temperature if a thermal zone is specified in the input; otherwise it is assumed equal to 20°C.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: How is the winding temperature rise at time t calculated?
output: The winding temperature rise at time t is calculated as: \( T_winding(t) = P(t)^1.6*T_winding.ref \)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: How can the transformer efficiency at time t be calculated?
output: Based on the derived total energy losses in a transformer the transformer efficiency at time t can be calculated according to the following equation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: What is the equation for transformer efficiency at time t?
output: The transformer efficiency at time t is calculated as: \( \\eta (t) = \\fracLoad(t)Load(t) + NL + LL(t) \)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does the procedure describe?
output: The above procedure describes how to calculate the total transformer energy losses based on the no load loss and load loss at rated conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does the transformer model support in addition to the basic calculation?
output: The transformer model also supports the case when the nominal transformer efficiency is given.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What information is needed if the nominal transformer efficiency is given?
output: In this case the user needs to provide the nameplate efficiency and the corresponding per unit load the maximum efficiency and the corresponding per unit load and the reference conductor temperature at which the nameplate efficiency is measured.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: How can no load loss and load loss at rated conditions be derived?
output: Given these information both no load loss and load loss at rated conditions can be derived.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: How can the nameplate efficiency be expressed?
output: The nameplate efficiency can be expressed as: \( \\eta_np = \\fracS_B*P_npS_B*P_np + NL + LL*P_np^2*f_Tnp \)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( \\eta_np \) represent?
output: \( \\eta_np \) is the nameplate efficiency

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( P_np \) represent?
output: \( P_np \) is the per unit load at which the nameplate efficiency is measured

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does \( f_Tnp \) represent?
output: \( f_Tnp \) is the applied temperature correction factor for the nameplate

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What are the thermal coefficients of resistance for aluminum and copper?
output: The thermal coefficient of resistance for the winding material is 225 for aluminum and 234.5 for copper.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What is \(T_windingref\)?
output: \(T_windingref\) is the winding temperature rise at the full load reference conditions (\(^\circ\)C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What is \(T_winding(t)\)?
output: \(T_winding(t)\) is the winding temperature rise at time t (\(^\circ\)C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What is \(T_ambref\)?
output: \(T_ambref\) is the ambient temperature at the reference condition ( = 20\(^\circ\)C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What is \(T_amb(t)\)?
output: \(T_amb(t)\) is the ambient temperature at time t (\(^\circ\)C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: How is the ambient temperature \(T_amb(t)\) determined?
output: The Ambient temperature \(T_amb(t)\) is equal to the zone temperature if a thermal zone is specified in the input; otherwise it is assumed equal to 20\(^\circ\)C.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: How is the winding temperature rise at time t calculated?
output: The winding temperature rise at time t is calculated as: \(T_winding(t) = P(t)^1.6*T_winding.ref\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: How can the transformer efficiency at time t be calculated?
output: Based on the derived total energy losses in a transformer the transformer efficiency at time t can be calculated according to the following equation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: What is the equation for transformer efficiency at time t?
output: \(\eta (t) = \fracLoad(t)Load(t) + NL + LL(t)\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does the above procedure describe?
output: The above procedure describes how to calculate the total transformer energy losses based on the no load loss and load loss at rated conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does the transformer model support?
output: The transformer model also supports the case when the nominal transformer efficiency is given.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What information does the user need to provide if the nominal transformer efficiency is given?
output: The user needs to provide the nameplate efficiency and the corresponding per unit load the maximum efficiency and the corresponding per unit load and the reference conductor temperature at which the nameplate efficiency is measured.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What can be derived given the information about nominal transformer efficiency?
output: Both no load loss and load loss at rated conditions can be derived.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: How can the nameplate efficiency be expressed?
output: The nameplate efficiency can be expressed as follows.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: What is the equation for nameplate efficiency?
output: \(\eta_np = \fracS_B*P_npS_B*P_np + NL + LL*P_np^2*f_Tnp\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does maximum efficiency generally occur?
output: Maximum efficiency generally occurs when the load loss is equal to the no-load loss.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What relationship can be established because the no-load loss does not vary with the load on the transformer?
output: The following relationship can be established: \(NL = LL_max\eta = LL*P_max\eta ^2*f_Tmax-\eta\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: What is the equation relating no-load loss and load loss for maximum efficiency?
output: The equation is \(NL = LL_max\eta = LL*P_max\eta ^2*f_Tmax-\eta\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What is reasonable to assume about the applied temperature correction factors?
output: It is reasonable to assume that the applied temperature correction factors are equal at the nameplate efficiency and the maximum efficiency.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What does the assumption about equal temperature correction factors imply?
output: This implies the following relationship: \(\fracLL_npLL_max\eta = \fracLL*P_np^2*f_TnpLL*P_max\eta^2*f_Tmax-\eta = \left( \fracP_npP_max\eta \right)^2\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: What is the equation for the ratio of load losses at nameplate and maximum efficiency?
output: \(\fracLL_npLL_max\eta = \fracLL*P_np^2*f_TnpLL*P_max\eta^2*f_Tmax-\eta = \left( \fracP_npP_max\eta \right)^2\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What results from rearranging Equation~\\refeq:ElecLoadLLnpOverLLmaxeta865 and combining it with Equation~\\refeq:ElecLoadNL864?
output: Rearranging and combining the equations leads to: \(LL_np = LL_max\eta*\left( \fracP_npP_max\eta \right)^2 = NL*\left( \fracP_npP_max\eta \right)^2\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: What is the equation for load loss at nameplate efficiency?
output: The equation is \(LL_np = LL_max\eta*\left( \fracP_npP_max\eta \right)^2 = NL*\left( \fracP_npP_max\eta \right)^2\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What can be obtained by combining Equations~\\refeq:ElecLoadetanp863 and~\\refeq:ElecLoadLLnp866?
output: We can obtain the no load loss as follows.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: What is the equation for no load loss?
output: The equation is \(NL = \fracS_B*P_np*(1 - \eta_np)\eta_np*\left[ 1 + \left( \fracP_refP_max\eta \right)^2 \right]\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: How can the load loss at rated conditions be calculated?
output: Substitute NL into Equation~\\refeq:ElecLoadNL864 we can calculate the load loss at rated conditions as follows.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: What is the equation for load loss at rated conditions?
output: The equation is \(LL = \fracNLf_Tmax-\eta*P_max\eta^2 = \fracNLf_Tnp*P_max\eta^2\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: When does maximum efficiency generally occur in transformers?
output: Maximum efficiency generally occurs when the load loss is equal to the no-load loss.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What relationship can be established regarding no-load loss and load on the transformer?
output: Because the no-load loss does not vary with the load on the transformer a specific relationship can be established.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: What is the equation for no-load loss in terms of maximum efficiency?
output: NL = LL_max\\eta = LL*P_max\\eta ^2*f_Tmax-\\eta

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What are the components of the equation for no-load loss?
output: In the equation \\(P_max\\eta\\) is the per unit load at which the maximum efficiency is obtained and \\(f_Tmax-\\eta\\) is the applied temperature correction factor for the maximum efficiency.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: How do transformers typically compare in terms of per unit loads for nameplate efficiency and maximum efficiency?
output: Transformers typically have close per unit loads for the nameplate efficiency and the maximum efficiency.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What assumption is reasonable regarding applied temperature correction factors at nameplate and maximum efficiencies?
output: It is reasonable to assume that the applied temperature correction factors are equal at those two efficiencies.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: What equation is derived from the assumption about temperature correction factors?
output: \\fracLL_npLL_max\\eta = \\fracLL*P_np^2*f_TnpLL*P_max\\eta^2*f_Tmax-\\eta = \\left( \\fracP_npP_max\\eta \\right)^2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What is obtained by rearranging the equation about load loss ratios?
output: Rearranging leads to an equation for LL_np in terms of LL_max\\eta.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: What is the equation for LL_np after rearranging?
output: LL_np = LL_max\\eta*\\left( \\fracP_npP_max\\eta \\right)^2 = NL*\\left( \\fracP_npP_max\\eta \\right)^2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: What equation combines the results to express no load loss?
output: NL = \\fracS_B*P_np*(1 - \\eta_np)\\eta_np*\\left[ 1 + \\left( \\fracP_refP_max\\eta \\right)^2 \\right]

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What can be calculated by substituting NL into the equation for load loss?
output: The load loss at rated conditions can be calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> equation
input: What is the equation for load loss at rated conditions?
output: LL = \\fracNLf_Tmax-\\eta*P_max\\eta^2 = \\fracNLf_Tnp*P_max\\eta^2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: How can total energy losses in a transformer at time t be calculated?
output: Since both no load and load losses at rated conditions are known the total energy losses in a transformer at time t can then be calculated according to the relevant equation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Electric Load Center Distribution Manager -> text
input: What references are provided for further reading on energy conservation standards for distribution transformers?
output: The references provided are: Barnes PR. JW. Van Dyke BW. McConnell and S. Das. 1996. Determination Analysis of Energy Conservation Standards for Distribution Transformer ORNL-6847. Oak Ridge National Laboratory Oak Ridge TN. Barnes PR. S. Das BW. McConnell and JW. Van Dyke. 1997. Supplement to the 'Determination Analysis (ORNL-6847) and Analysis of the NEMA Efficiency Standard for Distribution Transformer ORNL-6925. Oak Ridge National Laboratory Oak Ridge TN. NEMA. 2002. NEMA Standards Publication TP 1-2002: Guide for Determining Energy Efficiency for Distribution Transformers. National Electrical Manufactures Association Rosslyn VA.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What was the engine-driven generator model originally developed for?
output: The engine-driven generator model was originally developed for the BLAST program and was subsequently adapted for use in EnergyPlus.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What type of equations does the model use for the generator?
output: The model uses quadratic fits to the PLR (Part Load Ratio) of the generator.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What must the coefficients be derived from for the generator model?
output: The coefficients must be derived from manufacturers data.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What equation represents the efficiency of the generator in terms of electric energy output and fuel energy input?
output: \\( \\fracelectric~energy~outputfuel~energy~input = \\fracelectric~energy~output\\left( \\dot m_fuel\\left\\ kg/s \\right\\ \\cdot LHV\\left\\ J/kg \\right\\ \\right) = a_1 + a_2PLR + a_3PLR^2 \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: How are the electrical load and engine generator nominal load capacity used?
output: They are used to compute the part load ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the equation for the part load ratio (PLR)?
output: \\( PLR = \\fracElectric~energy~outputnominal~generating~capacity \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What is used if a stack heat exchanger is used to recover waste heat from the exhaust?
output: The exhaust gas temp and flow rate are used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What equation represents the total exhaust heat in terms of fuel energy input?
output: \\( \\fracTotal~Exhaust~heatfuel~energy~input = \\fracTotal~Exhaust~heat\\left( \\dot m_fuel\\left\\ kg/s \\right\\ \\cdot LHV\\left\\ J/kg \\right\\ \\right) = d_1 + d_2PLR + d_3PLR^2 \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What equation represents the exhaust gas temperature in terms of fuel energy input?
output: \\( \\fracExhaust~Gas~Temp~\\left\\ K \\right\\fuel~energy~input = \\fracExhaust~Gas~Temp\\\\\\left\\ K \\right\\\\left( \\dot m_fuel\\left\\ kg/s \\right\\ \\cdot LHV\\left\\ J/kg \\right\\ \\right) = e_1 + e_2PLR + e_3PLR^2 \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: How is the exhaust flow rate calculated?
output: \\( \\dot m_exhaust = \\fracTotal~Exhaust~heatCp_exhaust \\cdot \\left( T_exhaust - T_reference \\right) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What is the reference temperature for the fuel lower heating value?
output: The reference temperature for the fuel lower heating value is given as 25\\(^\\circ\\)C in manufacturer's data.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the equation for the stack temperature?
output: \\( T_stack = T_DesignMinExhaust + \\frac\\left( T_exhaust - T_DesignMinExhaust \\right)\\rmexp\\left( \\frac\\rmUA\\rm\\dot m_\\rmexhaustCp_exhaust \\right)^2 \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: How is heat recovered from the lube oil and the water jacket accounted for?
output: Heat recovered from the lube oil and the water jacket is accounted for using specific equations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What equation represents the recoverable jacket heat in terms of fuel energy input?
output: \\( \\fracRecoverable~jacket~heatfuel~energy~input = \\fracRecoverable~jacket~heat\\left( \\dot m_fuel\\left\\ kg/s \\right\\ \\cdot LHV\\left\\ J/kg \\right\\ \\right) = b_1 + b_2PLR + b_3PLR^2 \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What equation represents the recoverable lube oil heat in terms of fuel energy input?
output: \\( \\fracRecoverable~lube~oil~heatfuel~energy~input = \\fracRecoverable~lube~oil~heat\\left( \\dot m_fuel\\left\\ kg/s \\right\\ \\cdot LHV\\left\\ J/kg \\right\\ \\right) = c_1 + c_2PLR + c_3PLR^2 \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What must the manufacturer supply for the generator model?
output: The manufacturer must supply the recoverable water jacket heat lube oil heat and exhaust heat and associated fuel consumption for a range of load conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: How is the data fit to the PLR to obtain the coefficients?
output: This data is fit to the PLR to obtain the fifteen a b c d and e coefficients.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What was the combustion turbine generator model originally developed for?
output: The combustion turbine generator model was originally developed for the BLAST program and was subsequently adapted for use in EnergyPlus.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What type of equations does the turbine generator model use?
output: The model uses equation fits to the PLR (Part Load Ratio) of the generator and the entering air temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What must the coefficients be derived from for the turbine generator model?
output: The coefficients must be derived from manufacturers data.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: How is the fuel input rate calculated for electric power generated in Watts?
output: The fuel input rate is calculated in J/s.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What equation represents the fuel energy input rate in terms of electric power output?
output: \\( \\frac\\rmfuel~energy~input~rate\\rmelectric~power~output = \\left[ a_1 + a_2PLR + a_3PLR^2 \\right] * \\left[ b_1 + b_2\\Delta T + b_3\\Delta T^2 \\right] \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: How are the electrical load and engine generator nominal load capacity used in the turbine generator model?
output: They are used to compute the part load ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the equation for the part load ratio (PLR) in the turbine generator model?
output: \\( PLR = \\frac\\rmElectric~energy~output\\rmnominal~generating~capacity \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What does the temperature difference show in the turbine generator model?
output: The temperature difference shows the deviation of ambient air temperature from the manufacturers design air temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the equation for recoverable jacket heat relative to fuel energy input?
output: \\fracRecoverable~jacket~heatfuel~energy~input = \\fracRecoverable~jacket~heat\\left( \\dot m_fuel\\left\\ kg/s \\right\\ \\cdot LHV\\left\\ J/kg \\right\\ \\right) = b_1 + b_2PLR + b_3PLR^2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the equation for recoverable lube oil heat relative to fuel energy input?
output: \\fracRecoverable~lube~oil~heatfuel~energy~input = \\fracRecoverable~lube~oil~heat\\left( \\dot m_fuel\\left\\ kg/s \\right\\ \\cdot LHV\\left\\ J/kg \\right\\ \\right) = c_1 + c_2PLR + c_3PLR^2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What must the manufacturer supply regarding heat and fuel consumption?
output: The manufacturer must supply the recoverable water jacket heat lube oil heat and exhaust heat and associated fuel consumption for a range of load conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: How is the supplied data used?
output: This data is then fit to the PLR to obtain the fifteen a b c d and e coefficients.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> text
input: What is the origin of the combustion turbine generator model?
output: The combustion turbine generator model was originally developed for the BLAST program and was subsequently adapted for use in EnergyPlus.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> text
input: What does the model use for calculations?
output: The model uses the following set of equations all of which are equation fits to the PLR (Part Load Ratio) of the generator and the entering air temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> text
input: How should the coefficients be derived?
output: The coefficients must be derived from manufacturers data.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> text
input: In what units is electric power generated and fuel input rate calculated?
output: For electric power generated in Watts the fuel input rate is calculated in J/s.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> equation
input: What is the equation for fuel energy input rate relative to electric power output?
output: \\frac\\rmfuel~energy~input~rate\\rmelectric~power~output = \\left[ a_1 + a_2PLR + a_3PLR^2 \\right] * \\left[ b_1 + b_2\\Delta T + b_3\\Delta T^2 \\right]

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> text
input: What are the electrical load and engine generator nominal load capacity used for?
output: The electrical load and engine generator nominal load capacity are used to compute the part load ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> equation
input: What is the equation for Part Load Ratio (PLR)?
output: PLR = \\frac\\rmElectric~energy~output\\rmnominal~generating~capacity

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> text
input: What does the temperature difference indicate?
output: The temperature difference shows the deviation of ambient air temperature from the manufacturers design air temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> equation
input: What is the equation for the temperature difference (ΔT)?
output: \\Delta T = T_air - T_design

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> text
input: How is the exhaust temperature calculated?
output: A second curve fit calculates the exhaust temperature (C) by multiplying the exhaust temperature (C) for a particular part load by a correction factor based on the deviation from design temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> equation
input: What is the equation for exhaust temperature (Texhaust)?
output: \\rmT_exhaust = \\left[ c_1 + c_2PLR + c_3PLR^2 \\right] * \\left[ d_1 + d_2\\Delta T + d_3\\Delta T^2 \\right]

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> text
input: When is the exhaust gas temperature used?
output: The exhaust gas temp is used if a stack heat exchanger is used to recover waste heat from the exhaust.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> text
input: What does the exhaust gas temperature represent in the model?
output: This temperature is the inlet temperature to the heat exchanger which is modeled in a UA-effectiveness form.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> equation
input: What is the equation for stack temperature (Tstack)?
output: T_stack = T_DesignMinExhaust + \\frac\\left( T_exhaust - T_DesignMinExhaust \\right)\\rmexp\\left( \\frac\\rmUA\\rm\\dot m_\\rmexhaustCp_exhaust \\right)^2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> text
input: How is the design minimum exhaust temperature determined?
output: Where the design minimum exhaust temperature is a user input to the model and the exhaust mass flow rate and the UA are fit from manufacturers data.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> equation
input: What is the equation for UA in terms of nominal generating capacity?
output: UA = e_3(Nominal~Generating~Capacity)^e4

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> equation
input: What is the equation for exhaust gas flow rate relative to nominal generating capacity?
output: \\frac\\rmexhaust~gas~flow~rate\\rmNominal~Generating~Capacity = \\left[ f_1 + f_2\\Delta T + f_3\\Delta T^2 \\right]

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> text
input: How is heat recovered from the lube oil accounted for?
output: Finally heat recovered from the lube oil is accounted for as follows:

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Turbine Generator -> equation
input: What is the equation for recoverable lube oil heat relative to electric power generated?
output: \\frac\\rmRecoverable~lube~oil~heat\\rmelectric~power~generated = g_1 + g_2PLR + g_3PLR^2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: What are microturbine generators?
output: Microturbine generators are small combustion turbines that produce electricity on a relatively small scale (e.g. 25kW to 500kW).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: What does the microturbine generator model use to determine performance?
output: This model uses nominal performance at reference conditions along with several modifier curves to determine electrical power output and fuel use at non-reference conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: How should the modifier curve coefficients be derived?
output: The modifier curve coefficients must be derived from manufacturers data.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: What additional factors can be considered in the microturbine generator model?
output: Standby and ancillary power can also be taken into account.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the equation for the temperature difference \\( \\Delta T \\)?
output: \\( \\Delta T = T_air - T_design \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What does the second curve fit calculate?
output: The second curve fit calculates the exhaust temperature (C) by multiplying the exhaust temperature (C) for a particular part load by a correction factor based on the deviation from design temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the equation for the exhaust temperature \\( T_exhaust \\)?
output: \\( T_exhaust = \\left[ c_1 + c_2PLR + c_3PLR^2 \\right] * \\left[ d_1 + d_2\\Delta T + d_3\\Delta T^2 \\right] \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What is the exhaust gas temperature used for?
output: The exhaust gas temp is used if a stack heat exchanger is used to recover waste heat from the exhaust. This temperature is the inlet temperature to the heat exchanger which is modeled in a UA-effectiveness form.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the equation for the stack temperature \\( T_stack \\)?
output: \\( T_stack = T_DesignMinExhaust + \\frac\\left( T_exhaust - T_DesignMinExhaust \\right)\\exp\\left( \\fracUA\\dotm_exhaustCp_exhaust \\right)^2 \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What is the design minimum exhaust temperature?
output: The design minimum exhaust temperature is a user input to the model and the exhaust mass flow rate and the UA are fit from manufacturers data.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the equation for UA?
output: UA = e_3(Nominal~Generating~Capacity)^e4

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the equation for the exhaust gas flow rate to nominal generating capacity ratio?
output: \\( \\frac\\textexhaust gas flow rate\\textNominal Generating Capacity = \\left[ f_1 + f_2\\Delta T + f_3\\Delta T^2 \\right] \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: How is heat recovered from the lube oil accounted for?
output: Heat recovered from the lube oil is accounted for as follows.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the equation for recoverable lube oil heat to electric power generated ratio?
output: \\( \\frac\\textRecoverable lube oil heat\\textelectric power generated = g_1 + g_2PLR + g_3PLR^2 \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: What are microturbine generators?
output: Microturbine generators are small combustion turbines that produce electricity on a relatively small scale (e.g. 25kW to 500kW).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: What does the model for microturbine generators use to determine electrical power output and fuel use?
output: This model uses nominal performance at reference conditions along with several modifier curves to determine electrical power output and fuel use at non-reference conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: How can standby and ancillary power be accounted for in the microturbine generator model?
output: Standby and ancillary power can also be taken into account.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: How is exhaust air energy recovery for heating water modeled?
output: Exhaust air energy recovery for heating water can be also be modeled.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: How is thermal power output calculated in the microturbine generator model?
output: Similar to electrical power output thermal power (heat recovery to water) output is calculated using nominal performance at reference conditions with modifier curves to account for variations at non-reference conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: What objects are used to define the availability and control of electric generators in the simulation?
output: The ElectricLoadCenter:Generators and ElectricLoadCenter:Distribution objects are used to define the availability and control of the electric generators included in the simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: How is the full load electrical output of the generator determined?
output: For each simulation time step that the generator is being asked to operate the full load electrical output of the generator is determined using the user-defined reference electrical power output along with a bi-quadratic modifier curve to account for differences in the combustion air inlet temperature and elevation for the current simulation time step compared to the reference temperature and elevation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> equation
input: What is the equation for full load electrical power output \\( P_ElecFull~Load \\)?
output: \\( P_ElecFull~Load = P_ElecRef(PowerFTempElev) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> equation
input: What is the equation for the Electric Power Modifier Curve \\( PowerFTempElev \\)?
output: \\( PowerFTempElev = a_1 + a_2(T_ai) + a_3(T_ai)^2 + a_4(Elev) + a_5(Elev)^2 + a_6(T_ai)(Elev) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: What does \\( P_ElecFull~Load \\) represent?
output: \\( P_ElecFull~Load \\) is the full load electrical power output (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: What does \\( P_ElecRef \\) represent?
output: \\( P_ElecRef \\) is the reference electrical power output user input (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: What does \\( PowerFTempElev \\) represent?
output: \\( PowerFTempElev \\) is the user-defined Electric Power Modifier Curve (function of temperature and elevation) evaluated at the current combustion air inlet temperature and elevation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: What does \\( T_ai \\) represent?
output: \\( T_ai \\) is the combustion air inlet temperature (°C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Microturbine Generator -> text
input: What does \\( Elev \\) represent?
output: \\( Elev \\) is the elevation (m). This value is obtained from the Location object or the weather file.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: How is thermal power output calculated in EnergyPlus?
output: Thermal power (heat recovery to water) output is calculated using nominal performance at reference conditions with modifier curves to account for variations at non-reference conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What objects are used to define the availability and control of electric generators in EnergyPlus?
output: The ElectricLoadCenter:Generators and ElectricLoadCenter:Distribution objects are used to define the availability and control of the electric generators included in the simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: How is the full load electrical output of the generator determined for each simulation time step?
output: The full load electrical output of the generator is determined using the user-defined reference electrical power output along with a bi-quadratic modifier curve to account for differences in the combustion air inlet temperature and elevation for the current simulation time step compared to the reference temperature and elevation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the equation for full load electrical power output?
output: P_ElecFull~Load = P_ElecRef\\left( PowerFTempElev \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the formula for the Electric Power Modifier Curve?
output: PowerFTempElev = a_1 + a_2\\left( T_ai \\right) + a_3\\left( T_ai \\right)^2 + a_4\\left( Elev \\right) + a_5\\left( Elev \\right)^2 + a_6\\left( T_ai \\right)\\left( Elev \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What does the variable \\(P_ElecFull~Load\\) represent?
output: \\(P_ElecFull~Load\\) is the full load electrical power output (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What does the variable \\(P_ElecRef\\) represent?
output: \\(P_ElecRef\\) is the reference electrical power output user input (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What does the variable \\(PowerFTempElev\\) represent?
output: \\(PowerFTempElev\\) is the user-defined Electric Power Modifier Curve (function of temperature and elevation) evaluated at the current combustion air inlet temperature and elevation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: How is the full load electrical power output checked against user-specified limits?
output: P_ElecFull~Load = MIN\\left( P_ElecFull~LoadP_FLMax \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation

output: P_ElecFull~Load = MAX\\left( P_ElecFull~LoadP_FLMin \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: How is the actual electrical power output from the generator determined?
output: The actual (operating) electrical power output from the generator is determined based on the load requested by the Electric Load Center the generator's minimum and maximum part-load ratios and the ancillary power.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the equation for determining the operating electrical power output?
output: P_ElecOperating = MAX\\left( 0.0\\left( Load + P_Ancillary \\right) \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: How is the operating electrical power output limited by the full load electrical power output?
output: P_ElecOperating = MIN\\left( P_ElecOperatingP_ElecFull~Load \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the procedure for calculating the part-load ratio (PLR)?
output: IF ( P_ElecFull~Load > 0 ) THEN PLR = P_ElecOperating / P_ElecFull~Load PLR = MIN( PLR PLR_max ) PLR = MAX( PLR PLR_min ) ELSE PLR = 0 END IF

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the operating electrical power output using PLR?
output: P_ElecOperating = P_ElecFull~Load * PLR

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What does the variable \\(P_ElecOperating\\) represent?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
input: What does P_FLMax represent?
output: P_FLMax is the maximum Full Load Electrical Power Output user input (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Generators -> text
